ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improved speaking skills by learning new grammar and vocabulary.
Learned various new tenses in Korean and continued to further my vocabulary.
Expanded Korean vocabulary and grammatical structures. This level in particular taught me very useful grammatical phrases, allowing me to create and understand more complex sentences.
I learned a lot more Korean grammar and vocabulary.
I learned a lot more Korean grammar
Basics of Korean language/writing
I learned more how to use more advanced grammatical structures, as well as new levels of formality in speech.
My knowledge of conversational Korean and verb forms really improved in this course; it was harder than L1-L2, but not excessively so.
A better grammar understanding and a more extensive vocab. Also better ability to speak

KREN130 was a continuation of KREN110 and KREN120. It allowed me to greatly expand my vocabulary and grammar, as well as my speaking, writing, and listening skills. I also learned more about the different levels of formality used when speaking Korean. Additionally, we further explored Korean culture.

More advanced Korean grammar and vocabulary, enough so to form longer, more complex sentences and listen to more realistic conversations. Also, we were able to read stories (anecdotes/fairytales) for the first time in Korean
Basic/Intermediate korean grammar and vocabulary

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths include organized and engaging lesson plans. There were no weaknesses--this course was great!
Strength; very engaging and Professor gives additional 1:1 work whenever needed

Strengths: very welcoming, comfortable, and fun environment that is very conducive to learning. Great professor who is incredibly caring and good at guiding your learning.
Weaknesses: this class has less structure, so if you do not keep up with reviewing class material on your own, you will be cramming for tests
More speaking help would be nice
The course is thought very well
Could be improved by more TA sessions.

strengths:
High level of class engagement/participation makes the learning process easier: theres less pressure if you happen to mess up, because everyone else is making mistakes too.
Also, the class is geared towards learning practical conversational skills which makes barrier to entry lower, and you can more readily use what youve learned 

weaknesses:
Korean is a hard language and though it is no fault of the professor/textbook, it would be much more manageable if taught at a slightly slower pace.

I think the kind nature of the Korean department is what encourages so many students to pursue their interests in Korean language studies. I think in language learning, encouragement is so vital, and L3 was an appropriately more difficult course but this was a smooth transition with the resources and openness of the department. I would say the vocabulary is a bit much, and the review sessions only happened one day before the testI think in the future, it would be best to space the vocabulary out in brief quizzes, and to have the opportunity to review for exams/receive the exam material at least 3-4 days before the test.
View grammar rules that I still get switched up every once and a while. However, became much better at speaking conversationally

STRENGTHS: Professor Lim is such a great professor! He is very knowledgeable and motivates language learning by keeping class fun and interesting, giving fair assignments and tests, and being very approachable. He keeps students engaged during class and is very responsive to questions and emails. The class itself moves at a good pace and is very interesting. My Korean improved a lot by taking this course and continues to inspire my interest in the language and Korean culture! WEAKNESSES: None!

Strengths: The class dynamic really makes or breaks the course. All of my fellow students were wonderful and being able to closely interact with my peers made practicing every day much more enjoyable. Also, there is a lot of individual attention and practice with each new concept once we learn it 

Weaknesses: There isnt much effort made to reinforce past concepts in class, and is instead expected to be done solely outside of class. Some sort of incorporation of past lessons or daily small quizzes would help solidify things more

The course atmosphere is very mellow and positive. I think this makes the course very engaging to students, but the overall level of difficulty is pretty low. That's not a bad thing, but I definitely feel like a more intense curriculum could cover a lot more ground.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would highly recommend Korean class especially under the expertise of Professor Lim.
Yes, it's a lovely course with lots of activity and is engaging for students.
Yes!  is a wonderful professor, and Korean is a great language to learn!
Yes, if you are interested in improving your Korean
Yes
Yes, the professor was very nice and helpful.
If they have already begun learning Korean, then absolutely, L3 is a great next step. Its the class to begin to polish elementary skills, and then go on to learn more advanced skills.
Absolutely.
Yes, of course. Professor Lim is the best :)

Yes! Not only do you learn a lot of Korean in this class, it is also very fun and the classroom environment is very welcoming and engaging. The workload is not high yet this class is very conducive to learning. Additionally, Professor Lim is amazing! Definitely one of my favorite professors and classes at Yale.

Absolutely. Taking Korean at Yale was one of the best decisions Ive made here. The department and professors truly care for each and every student and take the time and effort to help each of them succeed. I actually already do recommend Korean to my friends looking for a language
Yes! It's a lot of fun, it builds well upon previous korean courses, and it expands a student's grammar and the spectrum of phrases they can use.
